title: Gangtok Himalayan SC
text:
Gangtok Himalayan Sporting Club, or simply Gangtok SC (formerly known as Sikkim Himalayan SC), is an Indian professional <a href="association%20football">football</a> club based in <a href="Gangtok">Gangtok</a>, <a href="Sikkim">Sikkim</a>. The club usually participated in the <a href="I-League%202nd%20Division">I-League 2nd Division</a>, the second tier of <a href="Indian%20football%20league%20system">Indian football league system</a>. The club currently competes in the <a href="Sikkim%20Premier%20Division%20League">Sikkim Premier Division League</a>. They are also a constant participant of the <a href="Sikkim%20Gold%20Cup">Sikkim Gold Cup</a>, a premier club tournament in the state.
History.
Formation and journey.
Gangtok Himalayan SC was founded in 2012 in <a href="Gangtok">Gangtok</a>, the capital city of the Indian state <a href="Sikkim">Sikkim</a>, and affiliated with <a href="Sikkim%20Football%20Association">Sikkim Football Association</a> (SFA). Since then, they have been participating in various domestic and amateur tournaments regionally. The club was founded by Tenzing Lamtha.
In October 2014, Gangtok Himalayan participated in <a href="Sikkim%20Gold%20Cup">Sikkim Governor's Gold</a> and reached to the semi-finals, but their journey ended with a 2–1 defeat to <a href="ONGC%20FC">ONGC FC</a>.
In January 2016, they were officially certified by the <a href="All%20India%20Football%20Federation">All India Football Federation</a> to participate in the <a href="I-League%202nd%20Division">I-League 2nd Division</a>, the second tier of <a href="football%20in%20India">football in India</a>, after finishing 2nd in the <a href="Sikkim%20Premier%20Division%20League">Sikkim Premier Division League</a>. This move began a new chapter for Gangtok-based side as they became a professional football club from the <a href="North%20East%20India">North East India</a>.
2016 was the most successful season for Gangtok Himalayan, in which they participated in the I-League 2nd Division, <a href="Durand%20Cup">Durand Cup</a>, <a href="Sikkim%20Gold%20Cup">Sikkim Gold Cup</a> and Sikkim Premier Division League.
After finishing 2nd in the group A (Eastern conference) of the <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20I-League%202nd%20Division">2015–16 I-League 2nd Division</a>, Gangtok Himalayan qualified for the <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20I-League%202nd%20Division%20Final%20Round">2015–16 I-League 2nd Division Final Round</a>. There they finished as 5th and failed to qualify in the <a href="I-League">I-League</a>.
In <a href="2016%20Durand%20Cup">2016 Durand Cup</a>, the Himalayans finished 5th, behind <a href="Indian%20Navy">Indian Navy</a> in the group A with 6 points.
In 2019, they reached to the final of 39th edition of the <a href="Sikkim%20Gold%20Cup">Sikkim Governor's Gold Cup</a> final defeating Royal FC Siliguri 3–1, but lost the title winning match to <a href="Mohammedan%20S.C.%20%28Kolkata%29">Mohammedan Sporting</a> by 2–1 margin. In that year, Gangtok Himalayan lifted "Independence Day Football Tournament" trophy defeating Sikkim Aacraman FC via penalty shoot-out.
I-League fate.
The All India Football Federation were all set to invite bids for vacant spots in the <a href="I-League">I-League</a> and Gangtok-based Sikkim Himalayan football club (now Gangtok Himalayan) were one of the front-runners to join, but it was not materialized.
2020–present.
In 2020, Gangtok Himalayan went to Nepal for participating in the 18th <a href="Aaha%21%20Gold%20Cup">Aaha! Rara Gold Cup</a> but their journey ended after a 3–0 defeat to <a href="Three%20Star%20Club">Three Star Club</a> in quarter-finals.
Rivalry.
Gangtok Himalayan has a rivalry with their fellow Sikkim based club <a href="United%20Sikkim%20FC">United Sikkim FC</a>, whom they face in regional tournaments including Sikkim Premier Division League. The rivalry is sometimes referred to as "Sikkim Derby". Both the clubs use <a href="Paljor%20Stadium">Paljor Stadium</a> as their home grounds. One of their most memorable matches was on 9 November 2019 during <a href="Sikkim%20Gold%20Cup">Sikkim Governor's Gold Cup</a>, and Gangtok Himalayan won by 3–1 margin.
Stadium.
For <a href="I-League%202nd%20Division">I-League 2nd Division</a>, the club announced that they would play all their home matches at the 30,000 seater <a href="Paljor%20Stadium">Paljor Stadium</a> in the capital of <a href="Sikkim">Sikkim</a>, <a href="Gangtok">Gangtok</a>. The club has also used the stadium for matches of regional tournaments like <a href="Sikkim%20Premier%20Division%20League">Sikkim Premier Division League</a>. It was opened in 1943 and has <a href="AstroTurf">artificial turf</a>.
